revision.text:
{|{{Infobox ship begin |infobox caption=}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[File:Smsstreiter.jpg|300px]] |Ship caption=SMS ''Streiter'' }} {{Infobox ship class overview |Builders=*[[Yarrow Shipbuilders|Yarrow]], *[[Stabilimento Tecnico Triestino|STT]] *[[Ganz Works#Shipbuilding|Ganz-Danubius]] *Naval Dockyard, [[Pula|Pola]] |Operators=*{{Navy|Austria-Hungary}} *{{Navy|Greece}} |Class before= |Class after={{sclass-|Tátra|destroyer|4}} |Subclasses={{SMS|Warasdiner}} |Built range= |In commission range= |Total ships building= |Total ships planned= |Total ships completed=14 |Total ships cancelled= |Total ships active= |Total ships laid up= |Total ships lost=3 |Total ships retired=11 |Total ships scrapped= |Total ships preserved= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship type= |Ship displacement=*{{convert|400|t|LT|abbr=on}} standard *{{convert|420|t|LT|abbr=on}} deep load |Ship length=*{{convert|68.4|m|ftin|abbr=on}} [[length overall|oa]] *{{convert|67.1|m|ftin|abbr=on}} [[length between perpendiculars|pp]] |Ship beam={{convert|6.25|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship draught={{convert|1.8|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship draft= |Ship propulsion=*4× [[Yarrow boiler]]s, *2× 4-cylinder [[Marine steam engine#Triple or multiple expansion|triple-expansion engines]] *2-shafts *{{convert|6000|ihp|kW|lk=in}} |Ship speed={{convert|28|kn}} |Ship range={{convert|500|nmi|abbr=on}} at {{convert|28|kn}} |Ship complement= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament=*1× 66 mm/45 gun, *7× 47 mm/44 guns *2× 45 cm (17.7 in) torpedo tubes |Ship armour= |Ship armor= |Ship aircraft= |Ship aircraft facilities= |Ship notes= }} |} The '''''Huszár'' class''' was a [[ship class|class]] of [[destroyer]]s built for the [[Austro-Hungarian Navy]] before the [[First World War]]. They were built to a design by the British shipbuilder [[Yarrow Shipbuilders]], who built the first ship, with a further 11 ships being built in Austrian and Hungarian yards between 1905 and 1909. A replacement ship was built when the lead ship was lost in an accident in 1908, and another ship of similar design building for the Chinese navy was seized on the outbreak of the [[First World War]]. Two ships were lost during the war, a single ship serving with the Greek Navy following the end of the war, and the remainder being scrapped. ==Design== In 1904, Austria-Hungary, keen to upgrade its navy, placed an order with the British torpedo-craft specialist [[Yarrow Shipbuilders|Yarrow]] for designs for a 400 t [[destroyer]] and a 200 t sea-going torpedo boat. Prototypes of both types would be built by Yarrow with production continuing in the [[Dual Monarchy|Austria-Hungary]], split between the [[Stabilimento Tecnico Triestino]] (STT) shipyard in [[Trieste]], Austria and the [[Ganz Works#Shipbuilding|Ganz-Danubius]] yard at [[Fiume]], Hungary.Gardiner and Gray 1985, pp. 337–338. [[File:Warasdiner2.JPG|thumb|left|SMS ''Warasdiner'']] Yarrow's destroyer design was a "turtleback" design similar to the Royal Navy's "thirty-knotters", and was based on Yarrow's {{sclass-|Ikazuchi|destroyer|4}} built for Japan.Friedman 2009, p. 59.{{cite web|last=Bennighof|first=Mike|authorlink=Michael Bennighof|title=Austria's Destroyers, Part One|url=http://www.avalanchepress.com/Aus_Destroyers1.php|publisher=Avalanche Press|accessdate=6 April 2014|date=May 2013}} The ship's hull was {{convert|68.4|m|ftin}} long [[length overall|overall]] and {{convert|67.1|m|ftin}} [[length between perpendiculars|between perpendiculars]], with a [[Beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|6.25|m|ftin}} and a [[Draft (hull)|draught]] of {{convert|1.8|m|ftin}}.Gardiner and Gray 1985, p. 338.Greger 1976, p. 42. They [[Displacement (ship)|displaced]] {{convert|400|t|LT|lk=on}} standard and {{convert|420|t|LT|abbr=on}} deep load. The ships were powered by two four-cylinder [[Marine steam engine#Triple or multiple expansion|triple expansion steam engines]], fed by four [[Yarrow boiler]]s, rated at {{convert|6000|ihp|kW|abbr=on|lk=in}}, driving two shafts. This gave a speed of {{convert|28|kn}}. Four [[Funnel (ship)|funnel]]s were fitted. One innovation compared with the ''Ikazuchi''s was that the uptake to the forward funnel was trunked rearward, allowing the funnel to be moved aft, in turn making room for the ship's [[Bridge (nautical)|bridge]] to be situated well aft of the turtleback [[forecastle]]. This made the bridge much drier in high seas. The original armament consisted of a single 66 mm L/45 [[Škoda Works|Skoda]] gun{{#tag:ref|While the gun's actual [[calibre]] was 66 mm, it was usually referred to as a 7 cm gun in contemporary literature.Gardiner and Gray 1985, p. 330.|group=lower-alpha}}{{#tag:ref|L/45 refers to the length of the gun's barrel. In this case the barrel was 45 [[Caliber (artillery)|calibres]] long.|group=lower-alpha}} and seven 47 mm L/44 guns, with two {{convert|450|mm|in|abbr=on}} torpedo tubes, one in the well between the turtleback and the bridge, and one aft. ==History== The first ship, {{SMS|Huszár|1905|6}}{{#tag:ref|"SMS" stands for "''[[Seiner Majestät Schiff]]'' ", or "His Majesty's Ship" in German.|group=lower-alpha}} was laid down at Yarrow's London shipyard in September 1904, the ship launching on 31 March 1905 and completing on 19 September 1905, reaching {{convert|28.16|kn}}. Orders were placed for a further 11 ships to be built in Austria-Hungary. While STT was quick to begin work, with its first ship, {{SMS|Ulan}} being laid down in September 1905, work at the [[Ganz-Danubius]] yard at Fiume, which had been awarded a contract for six ships in order to split work between Austria and Hungary, was delayed by the need to construct [[Slipway|slips]] to build the ships, its first ship not being laid down until July 1907. Deliveries to the [[Austro-Hungarian Navy]] continued from September 1906 to December 1909. On 3 December 1908, ''Huszár'' ran aground near Traste on the Adriatic coast, the ship sinking on 12 December. A replacement ship, with the same name, was built at the Naval Dockyard, [[Pula|Pola]], using armament and other equipment salvaged from the sunken ship. The class was rearmed in 1912–1913, with five 66 mm L/30 guns replacing the 47 mm guns. In 1912, China placed an order with STT for a single destroyer based on the ''Huszár'' class, to be called ''Lung Tuan'', with twelve more ships ordered in 1913. Armament was to consist of two 12-pounder (76 mm) and four 3-pounder (47 mm) guns supplied by [[Armstrong Whitworth]], with two torpedo tubes. ''Lung Tuan'' was almost complete when the [[First World War]] broke out, and she was seized by Austria-Hungary, and towed to Pola for completion as {{SMS|Warasdiner}}, being armed with two 66 mm L/45 guns, four 66 mm L/30 guns and four 450 mm torpedo tubes. Two ships, ''Streiter'' and ''Wildfang'' were sunk during the war. The Austro-Hungarian Navy was dissolved after the end of the First World War, with its ships being split between the [[Allies of World War I|Allied]] nations.Gardiner and Gray 1985, p. 329. Eight ships were taken over by Italy and two by France in 1920, and were scrapped, while one ship, ''Ulan'', went to Greece, where it served as ''Smyrni'' until 1928. ==Ships== {| class="wikitable" |- !scope="col" width="150px"| Ship !scope="col" width="150px"| Builder !scope="col" width="150px"| Laid down !scope="col" width="150px"| Launched !scope="col" width="150px"| Completed !scope="col" width="300px"| Operational History |- | [[SMS Huszár (1905)|''Huszár'' (i)]] | [[Yarrow Shipbuilders]], London | September 1904 | 31 March 1905 | 19 September 1905 | Ran aground 3 December 1908 and sank 12 December 1908Chesneau and Kolesnick 1979, p. 281. |- | {{SMS|Ulan||2}} | [[Stabilimento Tecnico Triestino|STT]], [[Trieste]] | 27 September 1905 | 8 April 1906 | 21 September 1906 | Transferred to Greece 1920 as {{ship|Greek destroyer|Smyrni||2}}
Discarded 1928 |- | {{SMS|Streiter||2}} | STT, Trieste | 30 October 1905 | 16 June 1906 | 31 December 1906 | Sank following collision with {{SS|Petka}} off [[Lovran]], 16 April 1918. |- | {{SMS|Wildfang||2}} | STT, Trieste | 7 December 1905 | 29 August 1906 | 15 June 1907 | Mined off Peneda Island, 4 June 1917. |- | {{SMS|Scharfschutze||2}} | STT, Trieste | 12 April 1906 | 5 December 1906 | 15 September 1907 | To Italy 1920 and scrapped. |- | {{SMS|Uskoke||2}} | STT, Trieste | 1 September 1906 | 20 July 1907 | 31 December 1907 | To Italy 1920 and scrapped. |- | [[SMS Huszár (1910)|''Huszár'' (ii)]] | Naval Dockyard, [[Pula|Pola]] | 29 November 1909 | 20 December 1910 | 8 February 1911 | To Italy 1920 and scrapped. |- | {{SMS|Turul||2}} | [[Ganz Works#Shipbuilding|Ganz-Danubius]], [[Fiume]] | 27 July 1907 | 9 August 1908 | 31 December 1908 | To Italy 1920 and scrapped. |- | {{SMS|Pandur||2}} | Ganz-Danubius, Fiume | 2 August 1907 | 25 October 1908 | 31 January 1909 | To France 1920 and scrapped |- | {{SMS|Csikós||2}} | Ganz-Danubius, Fiume | 21 February 1908 | 24 January 1909 | 16 November 1909 | To Italy 1920 and scrapped. |- | {{SMS|Reka||2}} | Ganz-Danubius, Fiume | 13 August 1908 | 28 April 1909 | 31 December 1909 | To France 1920 and scrapped |- | {{SMS|Dinara||2}} | Ganz-Danubius, Fiume | 28 January 1909 | 16 October 1909 | 31 December 1909 | To Italy 1920 and scrapped. |- | {{SMS|Velebit||2}} | Ganz-Danubius, Fiume | 5 November 1908 | 24 July 1909 | 31 December 1909 | To Italy 1920 and scrapped. |- | {{SMS|Warasdiner||2}} | STT, Trieste | 1912Greger 1976, p. 44. | 1913 | 10 September 1914 | Built for China as ''Lung Tuan''
Seized by Austria-Hungary 1 August 1914 and completed at Pola
To Italy 1920 and scrapped. |} ==References== {{Research help|Mil}} ===Notes=== {{commons category|Huszar class destroyers}} {{reflist|group=lower-alpha}} ===Citations=== {{reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== *{{cite book|last1=Chesneau|first1=Roger|last2=Kolesnik|first2=Eugene M|title=Conway's All The World's Fighting Ships 1860–1905|year=1979|publisher=Conway Maritime Press|location=London|isbn=0-85177-133-5}} *{{cite book|last=Friedman|first=Norman|title=British Destroyers: From Earliest Days to the Second World War|year=2009|publisher=Seaforth Publishing|location=Barnsley, UK|isbn=978-1-84832-049-9}} *{{cite book|last1=Gardiner|first1=Robert|last2=Chesneau|first2=Roger|title=Conway's All The World's Fighting Ships 1922–1946|year=1980|publisher=Conway Maritime Press|location=London|isbn=0-85177-146-7}} *{{cite book|last1=Gardiner|first1=Robert|last2=Gray|first2=Randal|title=Conway's All The World's Fighting Ships 1906–1921|year=1985|publisher=Conway Maritime Press|location=London|isbn=0-85177-245-5}} *{{cite book|last=Greger|first=René|title=Austro-Hungarian Warships of World War I|year=1976|publisher=Ian Allen|location=London|isbn=0-7110-0623-7}} {{Austro-Hungarian Navy classes}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Huszar-class Destroyer}} [[Category:Destroyers of the Austro-Hungarian Navy]] [[Category:Destroyer classes]] [[Category:World War I destroyers of Austria-Hungary]]
